item.title: Why I Chose AWS Over Digital Ocean
item.description:
There’s no shortage of shills for Digital Ocean VM hosting on HackerNews lately. They extol the wonder of DO and disparage AWS. I view these accumulations of calumnies with curiosity, searching for the cogent retorts from AWS mavens. Finally, I broke down and threw $5 at a DO plan to see what I was missing. Turns out I’m not missing a thing.

The Good

  • Modern CSS feel with candy buttons and very simple, limited UI
  • Grandma could launch a VM

Expense

How do the shills keep yowling that DO is cheaper than EC2? The 8GB ram DO “droplet” is presently Â¢11.9/hr. On EC2 you can get a spot instance with that ram for Â¢0.3/hr. That’s right, for 1/3 of a penny per hour, I can get something bigger than the most powerful droplet on DO. Clearly DO is not “cheaper.”

item.title: AWS EC2 Spot Market Volatility
item.description:
The spot instance market does not often make sense. You first learn of it and think â€œWow! Why did I waste that money on a reserved instance when I can get the same price on demand?!?!?!â€ Then you see pricing curves like this:

$6/hr for an instance!? 5000% markup! That is stultifying. This m1.medium is a perfectly fungible resource. You can:

  • Pay on-demand rate of $0.12/hr
  • Reserve it for 3 years and pay a combined rate (amortizing down payment) of $0.042/hr
  • Rent it at the median Spot Market rate of $0.013/hr

$6/hr is 30% more than that most expensive instance AWS sells (hs1.8xlarge, $4.60/hr), and this instance is puny by comparison.
